summary: This is a defense motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys, Mark S. Cohen and Christian R. Everdell, requesting two forms of relief from Judge Alison J. Nathan. First, they seek an order compelling the government to disclose the identities of the three alleged victims (Victims 1-3) referenced in the indictment. Second, they request an order directing the Bureau of Prisons to improve Maxwell's detention conditions at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC), including releasing her to general population and granting her increased access to discovery materials to prepare her defense.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the filing attorneys, accused in the indictment. The motion argues for her right to a fair trial and improved detention conditions.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who is representing Ghislaine Maxwell and is a signatory to this motion.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who is representing Ghislaine Maxwell and is a signatory to this motion.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom this motion is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as the 'central figure' alleged to have engaged in misconduct with many victims. His prior detention and death are cited as reasons for Maxwell's harsh confinement conditions.

connections.description: Cohen is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys filing this motion on her behalf.
Everdell is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys filing this motion on her behalf.

keyFacts: The defense argues it cannot prepare a fair defense without knowing the identities of the three alleged victims (Victims 1-3) referenced in the indictment, as the alleged misconduct occurred roughly 25 years ago in multiple locations.

The motion claims Ghislaine Maxwell is being held under uniquely harsh conditions at the MDC, including 24-hour surveillance, former suicide watch protocols, and limited access to discovery, which the defense attributes to the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The government's initial discovery production of nearly 13,000 pages did not specifically identify any of Victims 1-3, according to the defense.
The defense states that many alleged victims have already spoken publicly, filed civil suits, and given depositions, undermining government concerns about witness intimidation.

The motion requests Maxwell be released to general population and be granted significantly more time to review discovery, arguing the current proposed 3 hours per day is insufficient for a case with voluminous documents.
